response.answer_text: What is the probability or risk of it? The controversy was sparked by the debate between Jack Ma and Tesla's Elon Musk, two of the world's most tech-savvy entrepreneurs.  At the World AI Summit (WAIC) in Shanghai, China, the two discussed the AI ​​issue for 5 minutes. There, the two disagreed on the risks and potential of artificial intelligence. Jack Ma says he was very optimistic about AI. Smart people like them have nothing to fear. In response, Mask said, "Technology is changing rapidly and it is going beyond our ability to understand." Of course, the two agreed that the world's biggest problem is population decline. These two traders are known as one of the most influential technology leaders in the present world. US-based businessman Mask developed his wealth from digital payment company PayPal. He now owns electric car maker Tesla, rocket maker SpaceX, and the tunnel transportation business The Boring Company. He helped establish Open AI, a San Francisco-based AI research institute in the United States news. Jack Ma, co-founder of e-commerce company Alibaba. Alibaba is competing with Amazon to win the world's top e-commerce company. Alibaba has made one of the world's largest investments in AI technology. China has set the goal of leading the world in artificial intelligence at the top of the top 20 in the United States. During the debate, Jack Ma basically raised the issue of how machine learning (ML) calculates a good workforce. This technology will give new ideas of how people think and will be accepted in due course. When people understand themselves, even more, the world can be improved. AI will help create new types of employment so that creative work can be done in less time. Jack Ma said, "I would leave if I had to work three or four days a week for the sake of artificial intelligence." At this time the life expectancy of people will be 120 years. There are a lot of things that nobody wants to do at this time. Adding artificial intelligence to a robot will help it take care of older people. Elon Musk, however, opposed the idea. According to him, AI will create huge unemployment. AI won't put anything into work. Perhaps the work of people will stand in AI writing. One time AI will write its own software. Human civilization will be at risk. Tesla's chief executive says, "Artificial intelligence will take control of people." However, Jack Ma said, "I've been hearing about this for the past two years. But we think it's impossible. "

From Man and Superman: Human History Bifurcates | Sramana Mitra I recently wrote a series titled The Future and also gave a talk on The Future of Capitalism. In those, I said that I am optimistic about the next couple of decades. I believe, strongly, that entrepreneurship and entrepreneurial capitalism can be democratized, and wealth can be created in the middle of the pyramid using capitalistic principles. In the next 2-3 decades, the potential for distributed capitalism is very high and the outcome should be extremely positive around the world. That is the mission upon which my current work with One Million by One Million is based. However, there is tremendous inequality due to technology and automation on the horizon. In the 30-50 year timeframe and beyond, technology and automation will create tremendous disruption. 60-80% of ALL jobs will, likely, get automated. Now, that is a scary situation. I am sure you’re thinking, ‘Oh, I’ve heard this before. Machines replacing jobs. New jobs always emerge.’ Yes, in the Industrial Revolution, for instance, that was a major concern, but we’ve seen tremendous job growth since then. This technology revolution is, however, different. Before, machines could not think. Now, they can. And because of the processing power available in tiny chips, they can think incredibly fast. Process unbelievable amounts of data in a nanosecond. Artificial Intelligence, Machine Learning, and Robotics are moving forward at breakneck pace right now. The march of automation looks pretty much unstoppable. Let me give you an example. China managed to do tremendous poverty reduction on the back of manufacturing over the last couple of decades. But no longer can industries employ huge masses of people and drag populations out of poverty. FoxConn, one of the largest manufacturing companies in China that makes iPhones for Apple, this May, eliminated 60,000 people out of their 150,000 work force. These people were replaced by robots. We can safely assume that India’s poverty reduction strategy cannot be manufacturing, because new factories would inevitably use robotics, not people. Agriculture is seeing very similar levels of automation as well, by the way. I’ll give you another example, this time software, not hardware. In the advertising industry, media buying and allocating budget to various types of advertisements, and various media outlets has been a crucial job. Today, advertising is shifting online rapidly. And media buying in the context of online advertising is a 100% automated job that is performed by software, not human beings. It’s all done with mathematical precision, measured in real-time, and human beings just cannot play in this rapid-fire software application game. Same thing happens in finance by the way, with real-time high-frequency trading where human beings simply play no role. Machines think, machines look at data, machines make decisions in split seconds. And machines replace white-collar jobs, not just blue-collar factory workers. Let’s talk about the field of medicine. If you think about what a doctor needs to do to diagnose an illness, she needs to consider all the symptoms, take into account all the test results, consider all the treatment options, factor in all the side-effects of various medications and their interplay with other medications the patient is already taking. This is, effectively, a multi-variate optimization problem that a doctor has to do in her head. And, she needs to keep up with all the new research and advances in medical science, and factor those in as well. The field of medicine is full of incorrect diagnosis and mistreatment of illnesses. Now, if you replace this whole process with software, which IBM is trying to do with their Watson supercomputer, medical diagnosis becomes a truly scientific, deterministic process. I can tell you, if I have the option of being diagnosed by software versus a human doctor, I would always prefer software. It will be far more accurate. In the medical field, there are also tremendous advances in robotic surgery. So, the medical field will get dramatically disrupted in the next 30 years. The legal profession will face similar disruption with lawyers getting replaced by software. There are, of course, both pros and cons in this disruption. If the medical profession can be automated to that extent, billions of people can have access to quality medical care. Today, this number is relatively low. That’d be a huge positive outcome of automation in the medical field, for example. In another industry – transportation – there’s already huge disruption underway. Some of you are already using services like Uber and Ola – these are replacements for taxis. Well, the taxi industry is a major employer, and this trend is going to destroy an enormous number of jobs, and this one isn’t even a few decades away – it’s here. Now. It’s upon us. Then we have self-driving cars. Autonomous vehicles including trucks that drive themselves. This technology is almost ready. If governments allow autonomous vehicles, this will eliminate the requirement for drivers. If you have a combination of ride-sharing a la Uber and autonomous cars, PricewaterhouseCoopers predicts that 99% of the vehicles on the roads can be removed altogether. The total size of the fleet will fall from 245 million vehicles to just 2.4 million vehicles. That eliminates entire professions like truck drivers, taxi drivers. Car ownership drops. That shrinks the car manufacturing industry dramatically. Car insurance industry gets decimated. Car service industry shrinks. Massive disruption. 10 million jobs will disappear. Artificial intelligence is a blooming technological advancement, from software’s like Alexa, to basic human command system. Every aspect of these technologies has been put to its best use. It is now turning a basic part of human lives. People need this technology in enterprises and even households. Artificial intelligence has made its way through all sectors of society. Every person is using this technology in some or the other way. Moreover, it is modified for different age groups and industrial sectors. The future of artificial intelligence is more fascinating than ever. People seem to have indulged in this debate for years now. Some say robots are the future and they will replicate humans completely. Another opinion is a human dependency on this sector will increase manifold. However, one thing is for sure, artificial intelligence is progressing faster than ever, and no one knows what might come next. Amongst all the debate, there are some predictions that one can consider: Prediction #1: Universal Usage Artificial intelligence is already a part of various everyday activities. The future might make humans completely dependent on this technology. For example, self-driving cars are being developed with artificial intelligence. There is no limit to this technology if it wants to make the human experience easier. Prediction #2: AI and robotics will merge Many have predicted that by applying this technology in robots multiple new inventions can be created. There are many effects this can have on humans. Like, robotics will completely alter the medical stream, probably being able to be able to cure anything easily. Prediction #3: Simpler work environment Unlike any other predictions, this one says that artificial intelligence will only enhance your work environment. It will make tedious tasks simpler and humans will be able to focus on key tasks. This will help in utilizing human resource to its best potential. Therefore, the future can be infinite and the changes can be unpredictable. Although, one thing is for sure this technology will change the dynamics of our lives.

When the industrial revolution is mentioned, what immediately comes to mind is steam engines, ironworkers, and textile mills. This was a transformative time in the late 18th and early 19th centuries because it marked the transition from an agrarian society to factory-based work. Shortly before the First World War, another phase of industrialization took place brought about by the expansion of steel and oil production, as well as the discovery of electricity. Fast-forward to the 1980s, and you see the rise of digital electronics as well as their impact on society, which marked the genesis of the digital revolution. What we now know as the Fourth Industrial Revolution is yet another transformation of the society, this time, driven by technological advancements. To be specific, the technological advancements in question are centered on Artificial Intelligence (AI), autonomous machines, and the Internet of Things (IoT). Basically, in the formative industrial revolution, brawn was replaced by steam. In the subsequent one, steam was substituted by electricity. The third one saw the introduction of computers. While what society has been relying on is intelligent rule-based systems, what has not been in use systems is systems that can learn. This is the crux of Artificial Intelligence in the prevailing technological transformation. So, what is the future of AI? Firstly, it is important to acknowledge that the journey to where we are with AI now has been long and treacherous. The quest for the development of this technology has wavered, experiencing multiple ‘winters' where it looked destined for dead ends and disappointment. Today, the situation is different as businesses, and even national governments are investing billions into AI Research and Development. Essentially, what was a plot device in science fiction movies is in the process of being actualized. Google is employing AI in the diagnosis of heart problems more rapidly and precisely, American Express is using bots to serve its clientele online, while hedge funds are deploying AI to beat the stock market. Today, researchers are not talking about a single AI invention. Instead, the tone has shifted towards hundreds of AI creations, each focused on resolving a complex challenge in society today. So, what is the future of AI? What we have now is referred to as ‘narrow’ AI because it is has been developed to perform small tasks such as helping with the navigation of your car's GPS systems, executing Amazon product recommendations, or facial recognition among others. However, the future of AI is the development of a self-teaching system that can outdo human input and intelligence in different disciplines whether it is playing chess or solving equations. Some scientists believe this objective will be realized in the next three decades, while others talk about centuries to come. What is certain is that the Fourth Industrial Revolution is already in motion.

Sadly, the future of the artificial intelligence is not so bright.  It does give me chills the moment I think about how much it can impact the world. It is even scarier how much it does impact the World as I am answering this question. Everything became so artificial that they decided to cover the intelligence as well. In my opinion, humanity created the artificial intelligence for quite different reasons that it is used for right now. Correct me if I am wrong but we did create it to make our lives easier, didn't we? We invented autonomous vehicles, and talkative fridges, automatic garages and what so not. But we forgot to protect ourselves along the lines. Did we think about our own security for a minute when we were entering our personal data in the systems? Did it even cross our minds that our trust in the devices can be used against us? I am pretty sure, we did not. The humanity created the artificial intelligence so it can help us. Yet we will be the ones trying to help ourselves get rid of it. Mark my words, it will be a tiring war. We will have to turn against everything we designed. It will be us against the monsters we gave life to. If we don’t stop the artificial intelligence, it will stop us. It will start controlling our lives instead of the other way around. As of now, we still have the matters in our own hands. Let's not forget about that yet. We still have the power to control it all. And yes, we don't have to go all the way through it. Because if we do, the AI will become unstoppable. Not you, me or anyone will be able to control what's happening in the World. And that's just something no alive soul wants to be a part of. The most powerful creatures of this planet will become those who are less in power. It is a messed up, isn't it? It terrifies me and it should do the same thing to those in charge. Because in my opinion, it is time to start. Artificial intelligence is meant to help people, not to do a damage to the world. Let's not contribute to that purpose even more.

What do you think about the future of artificial intelligence? It won’t take over. Humans control the planet and we won’t allow machines to take control away from us. It will just make our lives better in the end. We will just fill our lives with more useful smart machines. For the same reasons we put seat belts and air bags in cars, and safety guards on tools, and creates laws against the building and use of nuclear weapons, we humans are smart enough to not yet dangerous things hurt us. We make mistakes, and learn, but in the end, we find ways to protect ourselves from things that are dangerous to us. Whatever the risk of AI, we will find ways to protect ourselves from it, and in the end, we will only use the “good” forms of AI and prevent the bad forms from hurting us. AI will change society whoever. The big change is in the economy since we will use this new technology to automate the entire economy and this will convert wage income to capital income — the income always grows with the economic output, but it will all be rent collecting income, instead of labor income. So profits, and capital gains, land rents, and interest payments will make up all the income of an automated system. An economy based mostly on capital income can’t support a democracy because capital income is a winner take all game where a few people always win big and everyone else loses big. It guarantees levels of inequality that can’t support a society. The machine economy we have already created has driven the levels of inequality beyond what works to support a healthy society. Our society is sick, and getting worse, because of the rising inequality, which comes from our technology. As AI and technology advances, this scikness will only continue to grow. The sickness created by this has to be cured, and the cure is a Basic Income. We need to share the capital income as a public resource, and prevent it from being privately hoarded to cure this sickness. Because our society grew up on the back of labor income, our culture places high value on a work ethic which the rise of smart machines has destroyed. It’s hard for people to cope with change that happens this fast but we must because the machines aren’t going to stop getting smarter and the jobs aren’t coming back. AI is forcing a transition from a private labor income and private capital income economy to a private labor and PUBLIC capital income income economy and this change is going to be hard for a lot of people to accept. So the transition will be rough. It’s already rough — 9/11 and the great recession, Brexit, and Trump are all potholes on the path created by the rise of automation). But, once we get the world converted to public sharing of capital wealth through a world wide Basic Income, then things will get a LOT better very fast and we will harness AI to do massive good for the world.

As of 2020, 8 years into the most powerful wave of AI ever, the future of AI is in coming up with a THEORY of what Deep Learning is all about and what all those artificial neurons do and what role they play in coming up with the results at the inference time. What this theory will show is that Deep Learning is all about LINEAR quantum-like operators and transformation, in a manner very much related to Quantum Computers. The mystique of this latest wave of Deep Learning and AI has been (rightfully) centered around generalization, meaning how deep learning networks are able to come up with reasonable answers on data they never saw before, after lots of training, of course. And the key is presumed to be in the non-linearities in the activation layers of artificial neurons. The initial activation function favorite of sigmoid has been whittled down to ReLU, which is almost as simple as it can be, and actually looks rather linear:  But this supposed linearity is a taboo as of now, as it is taken as a gospel that the magic of generalization can only come from something non-linear, as linear systems are supposedly (way) too simple to account for the magic of deep learning. This sentiment has persisted ever since the initial critique of perceptrons by Minsky and Papert, that supposedly showed great limitations of early neural networks such as perceptrons. That critique, of inability to do XOR function, has received a huge amount of (misinterpreted) attention through the years. It as in fact rather specific and localized to the connectivity of input neurons, as opposed to some grandiose statement of ultimate limits of computation. It is true that the linearity in Deep Learning is not obvious and hard to see, as it is obscured by reams of real numbers floating around in deep networks. The key is in a DOMAIN TRANSFORMATION where operators become linear. Such transformations are well-known in other fields, notably Laplace-transform in Electrical Engineering (and other fields) where systems of (linear) differential equations are transformed to polynomial fractions in the complex variable s of the Laplace transform. As for critiques of linear systems being too simple in nature, see this little field of Quantum Mechanics to figure how complex it can get. The future of AI and Deep Learning as of 2020 is in unveiling of this transformation, demonstrated to be quantum-like and linear.

Perhaps it is safe to say that with the role of technology in our lives today, our future depends so much on how far we we will go with its development and advancement and its crucial role in reshaping and redefining our society as a whole. Artificial intelligence has grown so much that its value has been highly appreciated not just in the computer industry. The continuing pursuit to advance in more areas has been overwhelming that we see our future side by side with it taking our role and the ones we never thought we could devolve. Here are 6 ways AI might affect us in the future. 1. Automated Transportation We’re already seeing the beginnings of self-driving cars, though the vehicles are currently required to have a driver present at the wheel for safety. Despite these exciting developments, the technology isn’t perfect yet, and it will take a while for public acceptance to bring automated cars into widespread use. Google began testing a self-driving car in 2012, and since then, the U.S. Department of Transportation has released definitions of different levels of automation, with Google’s car classified as the first level down from full automation. Other transportation methods are closer to full automation, such as buses and trains. 2. Cyborg Technology One of the main limitations of being human is simply our own bodies—and brains. Researcher Shimon Whiteson thinks that in the future, we will be able to augment ourselves with computers and enhance many of our own natural abilities. Though many of these possible cyborg enhancements would be added for convenience, others might serve a more practical purpose. Yoky Matsuka of Nest believes that AI will become useful for people with amputated limbs, as the brain will be able to communicate with a robotic limb to give the patient more control. This kind of cyborg technology would significantly reduce the limitations that amputees deal with on a daily basis.  3. Taking over dangerous jobs Robots are already taking over some of the most hazardous jobs available, including bomb defusing. These robots aren’t quite robots yet, according to the BBC. They are technically drones, being used as the physical counterpart for defusing bombs, but requiring a human to control them, rather than using AI. Whatever their classification, they have saved thousands of lives by taking over one of the most dangerous jobs in the world. As technology improves, we will likely see more AI integration to help these machines function. Other jobs are also being reconsidered for robot integration. Welding, well known for producing toxic substances, intense heat, and earsplitting noise, can now be outsourced to robots in most cases. Robot Worx explains that robotic welding cells are already in use, and have safety features in place to help prevent human workers from fumes and other bodily harm. 4. Solving climate change Solving climate change might seem like a tall order from a robot, but as Stuart Russell explains, machines have more access to data than one person ever could—storing a mind-boggling number of statistics. Using big data, AI could one day identify trends and use that information to come up with solutions to the world’s biggest problems. 5. Robot as friends Who wouldn’t want a friend like C-3PO? At this stage, most robots are still emotionless and it’s hard to picture a robot you could relate to. However, a company in Japan has made the first big steps toward a robot companion—one who can understand and feel emotions. Introduced in 2014, “Pepper” the companion robot went on sale in 2015, with all 1,000 initial units selling out within a minute. The robot was programmed to read human emotions, develop its own emotions, and help its human friends stay happy. Pepper goes on sale in the U.S. in 2016, and more sophisticated friendly robots are sure to follow.  6. Improved elder care For many seniors, everyday life is a struggle, and many have to hire outside help to manage their care, or rely on family members. AI is at a stage where replacing this need isn’t too far off, says Matthew Taylor, computer scientist at Washington State University. “Home” robots could help seniors with everyday tasks and allow them to stay independent and in their homes for as long as possible, which improves their overall well-being. Although we don’t know the exact future, it is quite evident that interacting with AI will soon become an everyday activity. These interactions will clearly help our society evolve, particularly in regards to automated transportation, cyborgs, handling dangerous duties, solving climate change, friendships and improving the care of our elders. Beyond these six impacts, there are even more ways that AI technology can influence our future, and this very fact has professionals across multiple industries extremely excited for the ever-burgeoning future of artificial intelligence. The future of Artificial Intelligence: 6 ways it will impact everyday life Uncertain Knowledge and Reasoning in Artificial Intelligence

The past few years have been landmark years for advancements in artificial intelligence.  Recently, tech giants like Facebook and Google have created their own AI labs to produce robots capable of learning to play video games without any instructions. Google now has their own form of AI called Deep Learning, which in 2015 doubled in the amount of projects using it. A huge focus right now for startups and giants alike is to learn how to use AI to help better automate a machine’s ability to solve problems on the fly. There’s definite signs that machines with artificial intelligence will soon be taking over skilled manual work that now is typically handled by humans. Amazon recently showed interest in getting more robots working in its fulfillment centers by holding a contest called the Amazon Picking Challenge at a prominent robotics conference, which awarded $25,000 to the team that could design a robot to identify and grasp items from a storage shelf as quickly as possible. While this may seem like a trivial task for us, grasping items haphazardly arranged on a shelf requires intelligence, expert coordination, and an understanding of one’s environment — skills that up until this point have been quite difficult for robotkind. Amazon already employs the use of robots in its fulfillment centers according to the reports of those that have been given behind the scenes peeks. The word is that these centers are already highly automated and sophisticated, with robot workers that transport products between humans as endpoints in a finely tuned system. Amazon is not the only organization backing up innovations in artificial intelligence. TheDARPA Robotics Challenge, funded by the U.S. military, gave participants the lofty goal of designing humanoid robots capable of responding to highly dangerous disaster scenarios. Robots needed to make their way through a series of grueling challenges; testing their skills in everything from opening doors to operating power tools. The $2M prize ended up going to a participant who won because his robot could both walk and roll along on its knees. Facebook has been doing some interesting things in its AI lab with a deep learning AI capable of parsing language and holding meaningful conversations. They also recently started a personal assisting service called "M" that is using human workers to train future AI.  No other point in history has seen this much engagement in the development of artificial intelligence, and it’s showing. These past few years have been a shining moment in history for AI, with the epic unveiling of self learning robots. A new issue to ponder: How do we face our fears of a future AI mutiny? How do we keep new technologies in check? With the development of standards to prevent robots from ever turning on their makers, the next new advancements in artificial intelligence will be of interest to watch.

I think AI is going to be more influential in the SaaS industry, and that’s something we should all look forward to. AI will help a lot in removing tedious tasks for humans, leaving us more time to do jobs that need critical thinking and creativity, such as designing products or services, thinking of new brand campaigns, or dealing with human relationships. The last one is the most important, because that determines the success of your company. Keeping meaningful and productive relationships with customers is essential to remaining a profitable company, while healthy relations between people in the office is the key to meeting business objectives. Some applications of AI are already sweeping many tech-based industries, like insurance and finance, health, and even customer service firms. AI is powering robots that do geological surveys, calculate risks, talk to humans, record information, and capture data from interactions. Those are just some of the possibilities with AI. The expansion of AI use may also result in the transformation of work culture, where people will be more challenged to do better than robots and be knowledgeable in robot use. In the tech world, it would certainly be more advantageous, and more lucrative, to have credentials in machine learning, especially as robots would most likely provide the best solutions to business problems. That’s why this early, it’s imperative for companies like us to invest in AI, think of ways to integrate into our system, and teach employees what AI is about and how it will change the future. We’ve written an article on this at the Tenfold blog, aptly titled Process Audit: How to Prepare Your Team for AI. I believe AI is placing us on the cusp of a new level of global transparency. Enough data has been archived to discover many things, but we are not yet at the point of being able to make these discoveries. The technology certainly exists, but the latest advances are still difficult to implement broadly and lack the required financial investment, in some cases due to elusive monetary rewards. As we better understand how to efficiently implement AI and current implementations stabilize, our abilities will reach critical mass. The data to broadly identify criminal behavior, illegal actions, and compliance avoidance already exists. We also have the data to understand the impact of decisions and legislation that can improve the quality of life. The massive troves of medical data will soon be mined to discover cures and treatments. AI tools coupled with other advances will enable ever more sophisticated genetic engineering for an increasing range of biological systems. The reality is that human behavior will hinder this progress. Status quo is perceived to be the safe and sound approach. Bad actors will do their best to interfere, ironically adding to the evidence that will ultimately reveal them. Those in power over various doctrines will rally their followers to resist. The good news is that AI is increasingly within the reach of everyone. Tools and techniques are appearing at an accelerating rate. Anyone with a laptop, a few thousand dollars for compute power, and sufficient education has the tools to contribute to advancing AI. Certainly, many will not discover new techniques, but they can apply known models to additional corpora to gain new insights. AI is indeed the new electricity. More importantly, AI is at the equivalent stage of development as electricity was when AC and DC power were competing for dominance. response.answer_text: The Short Read: Emotionally Intelligent Software is the New AI Advanced digital tools have revolutionized the modern workplace. But CIOs often make the same mistake when choosing new software. They focus too much on user outcomes, and not enough on usability. Think about it. Everything we hear and read about emerging tech boils down to the promise for greater outcomes. It’s all about deeper insights, fewer errors, and higher productivity, all in less time. We see this now with the hype around artificial intelligence. AI-generated buzz is merited, but enhanced technological capabilities — no matter how intelligent — don’t matter if the tool is too difficult to use. Organizations need emotionally intelligent software to raise both outcomes and usability. Tools that can anticipate where frustration will occur and prevent a negative emotional response in users will be of the greatest value to companies and produce the highest ROI for CIOs. What does emotional intelligence have to do with technology?  Emotional intelligence, or EQ, is defined as the ability to understand and manage one’s own emotions, and to recognize, monitor, and influence the emotions of others. EQ is a critical “soft skill” for managers and employees alike. It’s rarely applied to technology, mainly because software doesn’t have emotions (yet…) — but the human end-user does. Anyone who has ever struggled to use a complex software platform knows how excruciatingly frustrating it can be. You have a job to do and you need to use a certain tool to do it. But the tool isn’t working for you. Time is passing, your stress is rising, and your productivity is declining. As excited as CIOs may be about implementing a promising new software solution, the road to adoption will be long and full of obstacles if the tool lacks emotional intelligence. Emotionally intelligent software is within reach If difficulty using software evokes a negative emotional response, employee productivity and performance will suffer. Digital adoption platforms add a layer of “emotional intelligence” to any software platform. With AI and machine learning capabilities, this breed of software uses data to anticipate where users will experience friction, a key indicator of employee frustration. It can proactively deploy onscreen assistance in the form of pop-ups to prevent user issues from arising. Digital adoption platforms ensure a positive emotional user experience by providing help and preventing the factors that contribute to user frustration. Think about how much more efficient, productive, and happy your employees will be if they don’t feel like pulling out their hair every time it’s time to use a software system. An EQ boost goes a long way  Digital tools have the power to skyrocket employee productivity and enhance virtually all business functions. It’s the CIO’s job to decide which tools will support the business strategy. It’s also their responsibility to ensure employees can use the tools effectively, without frustration or difficulty. Emotionally intelligent software solutions like digital adoption platforms prevent negative emotions among users so they can work better, not harder. This article was originally published on WalkMe’s blog.

It was mathematician and scientist Alan Turing who spent a lot of time after the Second World War on devising the Turing Test. Though it was basic, this test involved evaluating if it was possible for artificial intelligence to hold a realistic conversation with a person, thus convincing them that they were also human. Since Turing’s Test, AI was restricted to fundamental computer models. It was in 1955 when John McCarthy – a professor at MIT, coined the term “artificial intelligence”. During his tenure at MIT, he built an AI laboratory. Full List Processing (LISP) was developed by him there. LISP was a computer programming language for robotics intended to provide expansion potential as technology improvements happened with time. Though promise was shown by some base model machines – be it Shakey the Robot (1966) or Waseda University’s anthropomorphic androids WABOT-1 (1973) and WABOT-2 (1984), it wasn’t until 1990 when Rodney Brooks revitalized the concept of computer intelligence. But it took many more years for artificial intelligence to evolve as it was only in 2014 that Eugene, which was a chatbot program designed by the Russians, was able to successfully convince 33% of human judges. According to Turing’s original test, more than 30% was a pass, though plenty of room was left for stepping it up in the future. From its humble beginnings, artificial intelligence (AI) has evolved as perhaps the most significant technological advancement in recent decades across all industries. Be it the robotics aspect of AI, or the implementation of machine learning (ML) technologies that are driving useful insights from big data, the future seems to hold a lot of promise. In fact, the enhanced information extracted from large chunks of data is helping companies today to mitigate supply chain risks, improve customer retention rates, and do a lot more. An example of how these technologies could change the way we live and work became evident when Amazon introduced its Alexa in the workplace. However, many believe that the AI-powered, voice-activated device signals just the beginning. Thanks to NLP (natural language processing), which is made possible via machine learning, modern computers, hi-tech systems, and solutions can now know the context and meaning of sentences in a much better way. As NLP becomes more improved and refined, humans will start communicating with machines seamlessly exclusively via voice without the need of writing code for a command. Thus, professionals who can design and test devices based on NLP and voice-driven interactions are likely to be in high demand in the future. With the growing interest and implementation of artificial intelligence in various fields and the promising future the global machine learning market (predicted to grow to $8.8B by 2022 from $1.4B in 2017, according to a report by Research and Markets), there’s bound to be a wide variety in future jobs for data science professionals as well those specializing in AI and ML.

One can only make a calculated prediction regarding the advancement of artificial intelligence in subsequent years by assessing the progress that it has made in the past few decades. It has had a short yet eventful history, interspersed with sluggish blips and periods of massive and swift development. Artificial intelligence first shaped up as an academic and functional point of discussion in the 1940s and 50s. Growth was positive and extensive research-based breakthroughs were made in the field, especially in USA, bolstered by government funding. However, the graph turned stagnant in the next couple of decades, now known as the “AI winter” period.  Nevertheless, as new countries such as Japan and Germany joined the bandwagon, exponential growth was seen around the end of the previous millennium. In the last few years, monumental landmarks have been breached with the popularisation of driverless cars, the advent of autonomous weapons, conversational machines, order-to-task robots and the tapping of neural networks. Over the last five years AI research has grown by 12.9% annually worldwide. In 2020, AI has seeped into almost every sector which has a technological base and is facilitating a level of growth and productivity that has never been seen before. Several startups are incorporating AI-based tools as a part of their core functioning, with more expected to join the wagon in the next few years. Analysts have predicted the appearance of a new Industrial Revolution phase in the next 50 years, and the complete takeover of mechanical functioning by AI-based machines. The future holds several promises, as well as numerous uncertainties. While one can’t exactly gauge what shall happen, one can certainly be sure that it shall mark a new chapter for the human race. The future of artificial intelligence is… GOOD GUYS VS BAD GUYS! The bad guys quite likely more. In my own amateur way, I'll try to explain this. Artificial intelligence become “intelligent” by us feeding it data. BUT the data we are feeding it is coming from humans. And we are by no means perfect. We are biased, prejudiced, racist, sexist. And in the data that we feed to the artificial intelligence, there are bits upon bits of these flaws hidden in the data which we not be conscious about. We feed the artificial intelligence this data. It doesn't know anything about propaganda, it doesn't know anything about prejudices, it doesn't know about sexism and racism, so what do you end up with? A super “intelligence” that is horribly biased. And that is WRONG! The “bad guys” can consciously feed the artificial intelligence a bunch of flawed data like that and use it for their own advances. Now do you realize the potential danger that is to society? Another thing to consider is, this highly sophisticated technology is quite likely to be controlled by people that are already rich and powerful and that IS DANGEROUS! FOR ALL OF US. I DON'T HAVE TO EXPLAIN! Well, what can we do about that? Well this is where the good guys come in. They will be the ones scrutinizing the data that will be fed to the AI to ensure that there are none of such biases. BUT EVEN THAT, THEY ARE STILL HUMAN! AND MAY MISS THE MICRO BIASES HIDDEN DEEP WITHIN THE DATA! On the bright side, artificial intelligence is what could “potentially” bring this world to a Utopia. On the dark side though, it is what will wipe us all away from the surface of the earth and make us go extinct. Luck to humanity, Signing out, Peace, Kusi, Ruben.

Let this represent the enthymeme of the positive argument for Perception and Prediction. Let the following represent the positive argument for the more powerful and expressive generalization abiding in perspective and orthogonality. This capacity is only available with the alternative: the Readware metalanguage and learning system technology. Premise 1: The orthography of a language encapsulates orthogonality which is the generalization of the notion of perpendicularity to the linear surface. The rotating, scaling and abstract operations needed to symbolize a continuously rotating 3-D World using periodic and n-D spaces (places) necessitates learning such an anterior generalization. This explains why children are given alphabetic blocks to play with these scaling and rotating operations while learning to speak, read and write using the abstract symbols of their language. The alphabetic blocks, shapes, and places are perceived by fresh new minds uncluttered by dirt in all the corners and free of harness or rider. They need only this small set of unbiased instructions to begin a lifetime of learning and an odyssey through the world using their mind's eye merely from reading off the page of a book. Premise 2: An instruction set is said to be orthogonal if it lacks redundancy (i.e., there is only a single instruction that can be used to accomplish a given task) and is designed such that instructions can use any register in any addressing mode. Theory: The Arabic symbol set and English symbol set (among other languages). are registers for addressing modes. Even though the sounds of each language are different, and English speech sounds are ambiguous with respect to Arabic, --both Arabic and English sound symbols address the same set of instructions identified in Adi's Abstract Symbol Tables (below). Proof:   For a complete proof, see Adi, T. (2007). A theory of semantics based on old Arabic. In R. Gudwin, & J. Queiroz (Eds.), Semiotics and intelligent systems development (pp. 176-209). Hershey, PA & London: IGI Global. This terminology (in the headers of rows and columns) results from considering an instruction as a vector whose components are the instruction fields. One field identifies the registers to be operated upon (the linear, rows), and another specifies the addressing mode (the perpendicular). An orthogonal instruction set uniquely encodes all combinations of registers and addressing modes. Conclusion: Orthography in language allows us to spell out the objects, places, and spaces,— uniting us and rescuing that vagrant perspective. I am not referring to your gaze or your choice of words. Perspective is the ancient art of drawing solid objects on a two- dimensional surface to give or obtain a true (real) impression of their height, width, depth, and position in relation to each other when viewed from a particular point. Can you do that? Did you do that as a child? Did you draw houses and people in places and spaces? How did you learn to do that? Why? Isn't that what we're doing when we're reading an image, graph, map or a text? Orthogonality in programming language design is the ability to use various language features in arbitrary combinations with consistent results. As we progress towards the new year, artificial intelligence continues to propel enterprise goals and objectives. With high computational powers and machine learning advancements, business applications of AI are opening new and better opportunities across vectors. For this new year, providers of AI development services are aiming to improve business services and strategies with disruptive AI technologies. Read on to find out what all artificial intelligence trends in 2020 will impact your organization’s digital transformation journey. Chatbots Will Master Human Interactions 2019 witnessed a ubiquitous influence of chatbots across business portals, social media platforms, and dedicated mobile applications. However, AI is still struggling to abate the lackluster performance of chatbots topped with their malfunctioning in response to complex queries. With constant algorithmic advancements and models wired with self-learning algorithms, the year 2020 would initiate natural conversations with chatbots. However, before worrying about the future of AI it is necessary to first know what artificial general intelligence exactly is, what it would take to achieve it, and how far existing AI capabilities are from getting there. Actually what is Artificial General Intelligence? Artificial General Intelligence (AGI) can be defined as the ability of a machine to perform any task that a human can. Artificial intelligence systems, especially artificial general intelligence systems are designed with the human brain as their reference. Since we ourselves don’t have the comprehensive knowledge of our brains and its functioning, it is hard to model it and replicate it working. However, the creation of algorithms that can replicate the complex computational abilities of the human brain is theoretically possible, as suggested by the Church-Turing thesis, which states — in simple words — that given infinite time and memory, any kind of problem can be solved algorithmically. This makes sense since deep learning and other subsets of artificial intelligence are basically a function of memory, and having infinite (or a large enough amount of) memory can mean that problems of the highest possible levels of complexity can be solved using algorithms. Although it might be theoretically possible to replicate the functioning of a human brain, it is not practicable as of now. Thus, capability-wise, we are leaps and bounds away from achieving artificial general intelligence. However, time-wise, the rapid rate at which AI is developing new capabilities means that we might be get close to the inflection point when the AI research community surprises us with the development of artificial general intelligence. And experts have predicted the development of artificial intelligence to be achieved as early as by 2030. A survey of AI experts recently predicted the expected emergence of AGI or the singularity by the year 2060. Thus, although in terms of capability, we are far from achieving artificial general intelligence, the exponential advancement of AI research may possibly culminate into the invention of artificial general intelligence within our lifetime or by the end of this century. Whether the development of AGI will be beneficial for humanity or not is still up for debate and speculation. So is the exact estimate on the time it will take for the emergence of the first real-world AGI application. But one thing is for sure — the development of AGI will trigger a series of events and irreversible changes (good or bad) that will reshape the world and life as we know it, forever. Cheers!! Nikhilesh Reddy

I’m not wondering why everyone’s talking about the benefits of AI, most of us are astonished by the different ways that AI helps us in our daily life. Be it as simple as asking Siri to schedule an upcoming meeting or as intense as carrying out an automated robotic surgery with minimal/zero risk. But did you know that the same machine that aids mankind for the good is being used in equal or even more ways for harmful & dangerous activities? I believe there’re many answers here that support the benefits of AI, so do I. But It is also important to know its dangers so that we can prepare for the future outcomes and utilize AI for good. Here are some dangers of AI that we should be worried about right now. Deepfakes: Deepfakes is considered one of the famous dangers of AI where technology is used for altering digital content to defame a targeted person usually a celebrity. A Deepfake AI application uses two components, namely a “Generator” and a “Discriminator”. The generator creates the fake video clip while the discriminator identifies whether the clip is original or fake. As the discriminator identifies the clip as a fake one, the generator “learns” where to improve for the next time. This system is called a “Generative Adversarial Network” or “GAN”. In this system, not only the generator learns, but the discriminator to improves its algorithm to identify fake videos better every iteration. The risk of people believing in Deepfakes will persist until there is regulation upon such content. An example of a heated controversy is a video showing Donald Trump taunting Belgium regarding the Paris climate agreement. This calls to the governments to take measures to prevent deepfakes from being dangerous. Human-like Dos attacks: A denial of service attack is a cyber-attack where a cybercriminal prevents users from using a particular website/service/ application. It sends requests in large volumes which slows down the system. These attacks are usually sent from a single source. On the other hand, a distributed denial-of-service attack is sent from multiple sources that are coordinated. Cybercriminals infect computers connected to the internet with malware first which helps them form a botnet subsequently using it to launch a DDoS attack on a targeted system. Human-like DoS attacks use AI systems to launch attacks in which supervised and unsupervised machine learning algorithms play a vital role. Deploying cybersecurity systems with ML unsupervised algorithms might build an effective wall against these human-like DoS attacks. Spear phishing attacks: These are the most popular types of attacks by cybercriminals which persuade people to share sensitive information. They are usually combined with other social engineering attacks like site cloning which makes them look trustworthy. Emails, phone calls, SMS, etc. are the modes through which phishing attacks are carried out. It all starts from when a recipient clicks on a link sent by the hacker as it spreads malware. A spear-phishing attack is when an attacker focuses on a single target and sends a custom email/message. AI is being used to power these spear-phishing attacks and send personalised emails to a large number of people. Implementing Artificial Neural Networks would detect these automated spear-phishing attacks and make cybercriminals abandon their attacks. Swarm attacks: Swarm attacks are emerging to be one of the recent trends of cybersecurity threats. Cybercriminals enable swarm-based bots to collaborate and operate autonomously to pose attacks on a target. For example, Fortinet describes that in the context of swarm attacks, “Hivenets” replace botnets, and are compromised devices using AI that helps target vulnerable systems. To prevent swarm attacks, there needs to be consistent cybersecurity across the ecosystem with automated cybersecurity to match the swarm intelligence. AI-powered drones and vehicles by terrorists: With an increased number of terrorist groups and activity in the world, the equipment that these groups use to spread terror is also undergoing continuous sophistication. Easy access to artificial intelligence makes the situation more complicated. Many technologies like UAVs, facial recognition and machine-to-machine communication are available to everyone. The thought that armed UAVs replacing suicide bombers for terrorist groups tells us how far can the risks of AI go when in hands of terrorist groups. Controlling this is only possible through regulation and framing anti-terrorism laws. Read Other 7 Dangers of AI: All the Dangers of AI everyone should know about.

The simple answer is that the future of AI is the future of humanity. But it is useful to consider the cultural dimension of AI. Asian AI will be different from Western AI because East and West have different world views. All cultures have their roots in animism. In the ancient past, everything (and non-thing) was believed to be permeated by spirits. In European culture, we saw a split between spirit and matter, which partly explains why Europe developed natural science. China emerged from animism without separating spirit and matter. They instead identified Tao, the "mysterious power" that moves the universe. Literally everything and non-thing partakes in Tao. Taoism is a sophisticated form of animism. The reconciliation of spirit and matter became one of the guiding principles in Chinese culture (as it did in Japan). The Chinese, like the Japanese, have no fear of robots with embedded AI, because robots too parttake in Tao. One of the themes of the 21st century will be the reconciliation of spirit and matter - and all other opposites humans conceive in reality. A modern chess engine can crush any human grandmaster at the game, for example, but it couldn’t tell you what day of the week it is.
